data.title: Add support for custom cursors on desktop.
data.body:
Added support for setting a custom mouse cursor on the desktop. I added the setCursorImage method to the Input interface, since it seemed like the best place to put it - right underneath setCursorPosition.

Only LwjglInput has a non-empty implementation for now; I don't know if this is viable on any other platform - it's intended for desktop-only right now.

The method takes a Pixmap and hotspot params; a Pixmap works well for handling all of the byte juggling required by LWJGL's finicky Cursor class, since the final cursor image data must be an IntBuffer in ARGB8888 format, vertically flipped to allow for a lower-left origin, and only single-bit alpha transparency is supported (i.e., 0x00 or 0xFF).

The method works flawlessly on OSX 10.6.8 (Snow Leopard); it hasn't been tested on Windows or Linux. It works fine by loading the cursor image file via an AssetManager, and then passing the loaded Pixmap straight into the method. I'm sure there are other ways to load a Pixmap, but that's the only way I tested it with.

Please forgive the faux changes in IOSInput.java - there were nasty ^M characters floating around in there, and my git settings remove them automatically. I don't think they should be there anyway, so hope that's not a problem. ;)

data.title: JsonValue.remove() removes all childs to the left of target
BitmapFont has issues in rendering glyphs packed into a texture atlas
data.body:
Not sure if it's a bug, but seems like that with certain CJK fonts (at least with https://github.com/android/platform_frameworks_base/blob/master/data/fonts/MTLc3m.ttf?raw=true) there are issues in creating BitmapFont objects out of glyphs packed into a texture atlas.

I've put some sample code at https://gist.github.com/agatti/7180052 to reproduce the issue with the font mentioned above.  When running that code, I should see the Japanese glyph „Åô four times in different colours, using two font sizes (two Label objects, plus one raw TextureRegion drawn in a SpriteBatch, along with a call to BitmapFont.draw), however I only see the first CJK font and the TextureRegion drawn on screen (the label with the second CJK font and the BitmapFont.draw call won't show up).  I've debugged the issue a bit and seems like that the UV/U2V2 coordinates in the TextureRegion and what's being passed from BitmapCache differ, but I don't really see why this happens.

Thank you.

data.title: Support Mac OS 10.9 Mavericks
data.body:
I get this message after upgrading:
_java[3550] <Error>: The function `CGContextErase' is obsolete and will be removed in an upcoming update. Unfortunately, this application, or a library it uses, is using this obsolete function, and is thereby contributing to an overall degradation of system performance._

Maybe you can also update the stable build so libGDX can run under Mac with Java 1.7. This was only possible with the nightly build.
I don't want to depend on nightly builds for my engine.

data.title: TexturePacker2 is going wrong about the max sizes.
data.body:
In this file it is checking wrongly:

https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/extensions/gdx-tools/src/com/badlogic/gdx/tools/imagepacker/MaxRectsPacker.java

Line 95:
rect.width > settings.maxWidth || rect.height > settings.maxHeight

this should be rect.width >= settings.maxWidth || rect.height >= settings.maxHeight

otherwise you can't ever use the full maxWidth / maxHeight.
(similar checks happen after this as well)

data.title: Temp fix for mac build
Bullet: update to 2.82 rev 2704
data.body:
You probably don't want to look at the changes, it's huge, instead look at the individual commits.

This PR updates the bullet wrapper to version 2.82 rev 2704, but doesn't add the new functionality (like Featherstone and MLCP). It only updates the existing functionality of the wrapper with the bug fixes of 2.82.

It also includes some additional changes I had pending, closes #826 closes #836 and closes #837.

Tested on win64 and android.

This PR is mostly to check the others builds on jenkins, therefor will merge myself. I will try to create the swig interface for the new functionality tomorrow.

data.title: An exception in TexturePacker2 is thrown when packFileName ends with ".png"
data.body:
```
TexturePacker2.process("/home/suseika/Projects/tendiwa/server/modules/images/objects", "pack", "package.png");
```

Because atlas filename "package.png" here appears to be equal to the packed texture filename, this call dies with the following error log. Maybe the exception should be more specific? As far as I can see, right now it doesn't say anywhere in docs what exactly does the third argument mean (except one well-hidden place in the tutorials). I personally have mistaken it for the texture file's name and spent a whole hour trying to understand how comes that the package.png is generated and at the same time a seemingly unrelated exception is thrown.

Error log: 

```
Packing.........
Writing 1024x128: pack/package.png
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" java.lang.RuntimeException: Error packing files.
    at com.badlogic.gdx.tools.imagepacker.TexturePacker2.process(TexturePacker2.java:557)
    at org.tendiwa.client.GameScreen.<init>(GameScreen.java:19)
    at org.tendiwa.client.TendiwaGame.create(TendiwaGame.java:16)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication.mainLoop(LwjglApplication.java:136)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication$1.run(LwjglApplication.java:114)
Caused by: java.lang.Exception: Error processing directory:
/home/suseika/Projects/tendiwa/server/modules/images/objects
    at com.badlogic.gdx.tools.FileProcessor.process(FileProcessor.java:156)
    at     com.badlogic.gdx.tools.imagepacker.TexturePackerFileProcessor.process(TexturePackerFileProcessor.java:120)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.tools.FileProcessor.process(FileProcessor.java:120)
    at     com.badlogic.gdx.tools.imagepacker.TexturePackerFileProcessor.process(TexturePackerFileProcessor.java:99)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.tools.imagepacker.TexturePacker2.process(TexturePacker2.java:555)
    ... 4 more
Caused by: com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Error reading pack file: pack/package.png
    at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureAtlas$TextureAtlasData.<init>(TextureAtlas.java:177)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.tools.imagepacker.TexturePacker2.writePackFile(TexturePacker2.java:263)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.tools.imagepacker.TexturePacker2.pack(TexturePacker2.java:86)
    at     com.badlogic.gdx.tools.imagepacker.TexturePackerFileProcessor.processDir(TexturePackerFileProcessor.java:157)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.tools.FileProcessor.process(FileProcessor.java:154)
        ... 8 more
Caused by: com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Invalid line: 
    at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureAtlas.readValue(TextureAtlas.java:425)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureAtlas$TextureAtlasData.<init>(TextureAtlas.java:110)

```

data.title: Building libgdx for iOS as a ViewController
data.body: Hello! I got the chance to ask at apps-world if libgdx could be built as a view in iOS with the new RoboVM, if that wasn't a feature yet. I have already asked in the forums (http://www.badlogicgames.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=11011) and stackoverflow with no response.

data.title: Updated GLSurfaceViewCupcake to GLSurfaceView from Android 4.3 (API 18) so to properly support onAttachedToWindow and onDetachedFromWindow
data.body:
In my project I have to attach/detach the gdx surface view to/from different layouts.
It works great on all Android 4.x I've tested, actually API 15 and newer.
Unfortunately id doesn't work on older Android versions, I tested 2.2 and 2.3.3.
Especially in logcat I get weird errors about surface identity different from the expected one and the app crashes.
Note that all my tests are done on real devices.

I've started investigating and tracked down the issue. The class GLSurfaceViewCupcake is definitely responsible for the crash and the issue disappears after updating it to API 18 .

Relevant changes done to android.opengl.GLSurfaceView from Android 4.3 (API 18) and/or taken from the last version of GLSurfaceViewCupcake:
1. Added ResolutionStrategy to constructors.
2. Overridden onMeasure method so to use the specified resolution strategy.
3. Set format and type of the SurfaceHolder based on android sdk version.
4. Commented Renderer and EGLConfigChooser interfaces since we have to use the ones from GLSurfaceView.
5. In checkGLESVersion forced openGL ES version to a value lower than 2.0 because we can't use the hidden class SystemProperties.
   If Libdgx already has its own method to detect the openGL version supported by the device we might use it here.

Further notes:
By looking at the code I think that issues 704 and 715 are already fixed in API 18, not tested though.
